subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Tests and Business Rules
msgSnippet: ... Another approach might be to define a common Rule interface, and then compose Rules into a RuleSet: public interface Rule { public boolean fire(); } public
messageBody:
Mark Derricutt wrote:

>
> Are there any existing patterns/frameworks for implementing rule based
> logic cleanly?
>

Another approach might be to define a common Rule interface, and then compose
Rules into a RuleSet:

public interface Rule {
public boolean fire();
}

public class RuleSet implements Rule {

public void addRule(Rule rule) {
_rules.add(rule);
}

public boolean fire() {

Iterator rules = _rules.iterator();
while (rules.hasNext()) {
Rule rule = (Rule)rules.next();
boolean pass = rule.fire();
if (!pass) {
return false;
}
}
return true;
}

Concrete Rule instances can be constructed with the data necessary to fire
the rule as prescribed by their fire() method. The RuleSet is assembled with
a collection of Rule instances, with which a single call to fire() will
effectively accomplish the 'if' logic. Combining AND and OR operators takes
a bit more work.

This is probably more than is necessary for checking whether a field is
editable or not, but it does address the 'if' statement for generic
rule-based systems. The simplest approach is to simply refactor each test
into its own method, as you've already pointed out.

Hope this helps.

Mike
